subject: Ethics
title: Asimov's Laws and Their Limits
description: A short lesson to help you apply Asimov's Laws and Their Limits.

hook.text: In 1942, a sci-fi writer proposed three laws to keep robots safe. Engineers still quote them today.

buildup.text: Asimov's laws: don't harm humans, obey orders, protect yourselfâ€”in that priority order.

discovery.text: Sounds simple. But Asimov spent his entire career writing stories about how these laws break down.

twist.text: A robot told not to harm anyone might refuse to perform life-saving surgeryâ€”cutting flesh causes harm.

climax.text: Real AI doesn't follow hardcoded rules. It learns patterns. You can't just type 'be good' into code.

punchline.text: Asimov's laws were a plot device, not a blueprint.

quiz.question: Why don't Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics work for real AI?
options: They were never published widely enough
Real AI learns from data rather than following hardcoded rules
They only apply to physical robots
